programme.title: Magical Japanese
Magical Japanese
programme.desc: The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history, and culture. This episode looks at words related to mud. Explore the unique culture behind them.
programme.title: Magical Japanese - Season 1, Episode 1
programme.desc: The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history and culture. This episode focuses on words related to doro, or mud. Since ancient times, Japanese people have gotten muddy in the rice paddies, cultivating their main staple. Perhaps because of this, there are a surprising number of expressions related to mud in Japanese. And reflecting such a place of hard work, many of them are used in business situations. From his home in Kyoto Prefecture, poet and literary translator Peter MacMillan guides us through unique words born from "mud."

programme.desc: At dusk in summer, a woman is absorbed in reading a letter. This chic lady is actually an advertisement model for Mitsui Echigoya, one of the top kimono fabric stores in Edo.
In the pleasure quarters of Edo, a precious house cat stares longingly out the window at a crowd of people going to and fro. Telltale signs scattered about the room reveal why it appears to be upset.
programme.title: Ukiyo-e Edo-Life
programme.desc: At dusk in summer, a woman is absorbed in reading a letter; this chic lady is actually an advertisement model for Mitsui Echigoya, one of the top kimono fabric stores in Edo.

Centuries ago, Tokyo was known as Edo. More than a million people enjoyed life in this small but abundant city. They live on in ukiyo-e woodblock prints. Each episode is a deep dive into a single print, and an exploration of the soul of Old Tokyo. We examine works by artists like Hokusai and Hiroshige not just for their aesthetic and historical value, but for the stories they tell of everyday life. That is how the people of Edo themselves enjoyed this mass-produced medium.

Traveling across Japan, we can find many bridges of all shapes and sizes. In Tokyo, building modern bridges was one way to join the club of advanced industrial nations in the late 19th century, when Japan was vying to catch up with Western technology. A small bridge in Iwate Prefecture is hand-made. Even if relatively few people use it, it is an important crossing for the local community. Today, we hear the story of bridges linking communities throughout Japan.

MATSURI

programme.desc: Traditional festivals called matsuri are found all over Japan. In this series, we present diverse matsuri and the preparations leading up to them. Each matsuri presents a new face of local Japan. Inami Shishimai is a type of lion dance performed in Toyama Prefecture. Adults play the role of the shishi while a child is the shishi-tori, whose job is to pacify the shishi with sacred objects.

Inami Shishimai is a type of lion dance performed in Toyama Prefecture. Here, the shishi symbolizes the harshness and bounty of the natural world, and the matsuri focuses on the importance of harmony between people and nature. Adults play the role of the enormous shishi while a child is the shishi-tori, whose job is to pacify the shishi with sacred objects. This event is also an opportunity for local families to wish for happy marriages and children, and the shishi dances in celebration.

Hometown Stories
programme.desc: The Manyoshu is the oldest extant anthology of Japanese poetry. Through poems presented in both manga and modern settings, we glimpse sentiments from centuries ago. The topic this time is love. The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history, and culture. This episode looks at words related to mud. Explore the unique culture behind them.

The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history and culture. This episode focuses on words related to doro, or mud. Since ancient times, Japanese people have gotten muddy in the rice paddies, cultivating their main staple. Perhaps because of this, there are a surprising number of expressions related to mud in Japanese. And reflecting such a place of hard work, many of them are used in business situations. From his home in Kyoto Prefecture, poet and literary translator Peter MacMillan guides us through unique words born from "mud."

English-speaking visitors travel the length of Japan, exploring the local culture, meeting the people and offering travel hints rarely found in guidebooks. Get to know useful travel tips! Sheila Cliffe follows Japan's silk road from Tomioka to the port of Yokohama where she encounters architecture designed for silkworms, modernized reeling machinery, weavers and historians.
Sheila Cliffe follows Japan's Silk Road from Tomioka to the port of Yokohama where she encounters architecture designed for silkworms, modernised reeling machinery, weavers and historians.

In 1859, when Japan reopened its doors after more than two centuries of isolation, goods flowed in and out of newly expanded ports. At the time, raw silk became the country's largest export, as the silk industries in France and Italy had been hit by an epidemic of silkworm disease. At one point, Japan was the world's biggest exporter. On this episode of Journeys in Japan, Sheila Cliffe from the UK follows the Silk Road from northern Kanto, once a major production area, to Yokohama, where the silk took off to the world.

Journeys in Japan is a documentary series where English-speaking guides explore Japan's diverse regions, delving into local traditions, culture, and everyday life, offering viewers a unique look beyond typical tourist spots.

Documentary series that follows foreign visitors as they travel the length of Japan, explore the local culture, and meet some new and colourful people along the way. On their adventures, they will offer viewers a variety of valuable travel hints that can rarely be found in guidebooks.

Inami Shishimai is a type of lion dance performed in Toyama Prefecture - adults play the role of the shishi while a child is the shishi-tori, whose job is to pacify the shishi with sacred objects.

Inami Shishimai is a type of lion dance performed in Toyama Prefecture. Here, the shishi symbolizes the harshness and bounty of the natural world, and the matsuri focuses on the importance of harmony between people and nature. Adults play the role of the enormous shishi while a child is the shishi-tori, whose job is to pacify the shishi with sacred objects. This event is also an opportunity for local families to wish for happy marriages and children, and the shishi dances in celebration.

programme.title: Document 72 Hours
Document 72 Hours
programme.sub-title: A Mobile "Warabi Mochi" Cart in Fukuoka

Sheila Cliffe follows Japan's silk road from Tomioka to the port of Yokohama where she encounters architecture designed for silkworms, modernized reeling machinery, weavers and historians.
Sheila Cliffe follows Japan's Silk Road from Tomioka to the port of Yokohama where she encounters architecture designed for silkworms, modernised reeling machinery, weavers and historians.

In 1859, when Japan reopened its doors after more than two centuries of isolation, goods flowed in and out of newly expanded ports. At the time, raw silk became the country's largest export, as the silk industries in France and Italy had been hit by an epidemic of silkworm disease. At one point, Japan was the world's biggest exporter. On this episode of Journeys in Japan, Sheila Cliffe from the UK follows the Silk Road from northern Kanto, once a major production area, to Yokohama, where the silk took off to the world.

Documentary series that follows foreign visitors as they travel the length of Japan, explore the local culture, and meet some new and colourful people along the way. On their adventures, they will offer viewers a variety of valuable travel hints that can rarely be found in guidebooks.

programme.desc: When disaster strikes, it can be hard to find people trapped under rubble, while fire, volcanic eruption, or nuclear accidents may bar entry entirely. That's where disaster response robots can help.

Japan has a long history of natural disasters. BOSAI explores how to overcome them and save lives with the power of science. When disaster strikes, it can be hard to find people trapped under rubble, while fire, volcanic eruption, or nuclear accidents may bar entry entirely. That's where disaster response robots can help.
Disaster Response Robots: If disaster strikes, it can be hard to find people if fire, volcanic eruption, or nuclear accidents prevent smooth recovery - that's where robots can help.

The Great East Japan Earthquake in 2011 and its resulting tsunami caused the accident at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant. The worst nuclear accident in Japan's history suffered from a lack of information due to the inaccessibility of the reactor buildings. For this reason, "disaster response robots" were deployed to take pictures and measure radiation doses inside the buildings. In the aftermath of a major disaster like that as well as an earthquake or fire, robots can quickly enter dangerous sites that are inaccessible to humans, find people in need of rescue, and take detailed measurements to provide data about the site. In this episode, we'll look at the latest developments among Japan's "disaster response robots."

Sheila Cliffe follows Japan's silk road from Tomioka to the port of Yokohama where she encounters architecture designed for silkworms, modernized reeling machinery, weavers and historians.
Sheila Cliffe follows Japan's Silk Road from Tomioka to the port of Yokohama where she encounters architecture designed for silkworms, modernised reeling machinery, weavers and historians.

In 1859, when Japan reopened its doors after more than two centuries of isolation, goods flowed in and out of newly expanded ports. At the time, raw silk became the country's largest export, as the silk industries in France and Italy had been hit by an epidemic of silkworm disease. At one point, Japan was the world's biggest exporter. On this episode of Journeys in Japan, Sheila Cliffe from the UK follows the Silk Road from northern Kanto, once a major production area, to Yokohama, where the silk took off to the world.

Documentary series that follows foreign visitors as they travel the length of Japan, explore the local culture, and meet some new and colourful people along the way. On their adventures, they will offer viewers a variety of valuable travel hints that can rarely be found in guidebooks.

With its splendid branches and white plum blossoms, this famous painting is known for captivating Van Gogh. Discover...

Centuries ago, Tokyo was known as Edo. More than a million people enjoyed life in this small but abundant city. They live on in ukiyo-e woodblock prints. Each episode is a deep dive into a single print, and an exploration of the soul of Old Tokyo. We examine works by artists like Hokusai and Hiroshige not just for their aesthetic and historical value, but for the stories they tell of everyday life. That is how the people of Edo themselves enjoyed this mass-produced medium.

programme.title: Document 72 Hours
programme.desc: A mobile food cart selling a traditional Japanese sweet has been plying the streets of Fukuoka for over 75 years - for three days we talk to customers fond of a snack unchanged over the decades.

Journeys in Japan is a documentary series where English-speaking guides explore Japan's diverse regions, delving into local traditions, culture, and everyday life, offering viewers a unique look beyond typical tourist spots.

In 1859, when Japan reopened its doors after more than two centuries of isolation, goods flowed in and out of newly expanded ports. At the time, raw silk became the country's largest export, as the silk industries in France and Italy had been hit by an epidemic of silkworm disease. At one point, Japan was the world's biggest exporter. On this episode of Journeys in Japan, Sheila Cliffe from the UK follows the Silk Road from northern Kanto, once a major production area, to Yokohama, where the silk took off to the world.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Jidai Matsuri: A Parade of Period Costumes through the Ages
programme.desc: The Jidai Matsuri on October 22 pays homage to Kyoto's 1,200-year history, from the Meiji through the Heian periods, with 2,000 people parading in period costumes. The festival shows the Kyotoites' resilience as they redefined their city and created a new, modern Kyoto.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.sub-title: #40 Pointing out a senior coworker's mistake
programme.desc: Today: pointing out a senior coworker's mistake. Kyaw Swar Aung, from Myanmar, works behind the scenes at Narita Airport. He carries out tasks such as guiding aircraft as well as loading and unloading baggage. He's learned that both caution and precision are necessary to prevent accidents. He knows to report anything out of the ordinary, as well as any errors. He'll tackle a roleplay challenge in which he notices a senior worker's mistake. How will he handle the situation?

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: The Japanese southern island of Okinawa Prefecture, warm all year, this popular tourist spot is home to "Ryukyu Glass," a local industry for over 100 years. Glass blower Matsumoto Sakae insists on using discarded bottles as raw material. He says their status as trash inspires him to give them beauty, making things that will be loved and never again thrown away. Hoping, in some small way, to reduce waste in the world, he keeps his furnace hot and his tools ready.

programme.title: BOSAI:Disaster Response Robots
programme.desc: When disaster strikes, it can be hard to find people trapped under rubble, while fire, volcanic eruption, or nuclear accidents may bar entry entirely. Thats where disaster response robots can help.

The Great East Japan Earthquake in 2011 and its resulting tsunami caused the accident at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant. The worst nuclear accident in Japan's history suffered from a lack of information due to the inaccessibility of the reactor buildings. For this reason, "disaster response robots" were deployed to take pictures and measure radiation doses inside the buildings. In the aftermath of a major disaster like that as well as an earthquake or fire, robots can quickly enter dangerous sites that are inaccessible to humans, find people in need of rescue, and take detailed measurements to provide data about the site. In this episode, we'll look at the latest developments among Japan's "disaster response robots."
programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.desc: Documentary programme that allows viewers to discover more about the stunning Japan, through its incredible and long history, ancient traditions, local festivals, amazing and beloved food and daily life. Find out more about Japan's favorite citrus fruit, Ishigaki Island, "nabe" or hot pot, local train lines, Shinbashi, one of Tokyo's leading business districts, ''soba'' or Japan's beloved noodle, and much more.
programme.title: Magical Japanese - Season 1, Episode 1
Seasoning the Seasons
programme.desc: The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history and culture. This episode focuses on words related to doro, or mud. Since ancient times, Japanese people have gotten muddy in the rice paddies, cultivating their main staple. Perhaps because of this, there are a surprising number of expressions related to mud in Japanese. And reflecting such a place of hard work, many of them are used in business situations. From his home in Kyoto Prefecture, poet and literary translator Peter MacMillan guides us through unique words born from "mud."

programme.title: BIZ STREAM
programme.desc: This program visits places across Japan to introduce the charms of their local daily life and festivals fostered by the nations long history.

Traveling across Japan, we can find many bridges of all shapes and sizes. In Tokyo, building modern bridges was one way to join the club of advanced industrial nations in the late 19th century, when Japan was vying to catch up with Western technology. A small bridge in Iwate Prefecture is hand-made. Even if relatively few people use it, it is an important crossing for the local community. Today, we hear the story of bridges linking communities throughout Japan.

Herbal Symphony #3 Autumn
programme.desc: Inami Shishimai is a type of lion dance performed in Toyama Prefecture. Here, the shishi symbolizes the harshness and bounty of the natural world, and the matsuri focuses on the importance of harmony between people and nature. Adults play the role of the enormous shishi while a child is the shishi-tori, whose job is to pacify the shishi with sacred objects. This event is also an opportunity for local families to wish for happy marriages and children, and the shishi dances in celebration.

programme.title: Magical Japanese - Season 1, Episode 1
Seasoning the Seasons
programme.desc: The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history and culture. This episode focuses on words related to doro, or mud. Since ancient times, Japanese people have gotten muddy in the rice paddies, cultivating their main staple. Perhaps because of this, there are a surprising number of expressions related to mud in Japanese. And reflecting such a place of hard work, many of them are used in business situations. From his home in Kyoto Prefecture, poet and literary translator Peter MacMillan guides us through unique words born from "mud."

programme.title: Hometown Stories
programme.desc: This program visits places across Japan to introduce the charms of their local daily life and festivals fostered by the nations long history.

Traveling across Japan, we can find many bridges of all shapes and sizes. In Tokyo, building modern bridges was one way to join the club of advanced industrial nations in the late 19th century, when Japan was vying to catch up with Western technology. A small bridge in Iwate Prefecture is hand-made. Even if relatively few people use it, it is an important crossing for the local community. Today, we hear the story of bridges linking communities throughout Japan.

Herbal Symphony #3 Autumn
programme.desc: Inami Shishimai is a type of lion dance performed in Toyama Prefecture. Here, the shishi symbolizes the harshness and bounty of the natural world, and the matsuri focuses on the importance of harmony between people and nature. Adults play the role of the enormous shishi while a child is the shishi-tori, whose job is to pacify the shishi with sacred objects. This event is also an opportunity for local families to wish for happy marriages and children, and the shishi dances in celebration.

In the pleasure quarters of Edo, a precious house cat stares longingly out the window at a crowd of people going to and fro. Telltale signs scattered about the room reveal why it appears to be upset.
programme.title: Ukiyo-e Edo-Life
programme.desc: At dusk in summer, a woman is absorbed in reading a letter; this chic lady is actually an advertisement model for Mitsui Echigoya, one of the top kimono fabric stores in Edo.

Centuries ago, Tokyo was known as Edo. More than a million people enjoyed life in this small but abundant city. They live on in ukiyo-e woodblock prints. Each episode is a deep dive into a single print, and an exploration of the soul of Old Tokyo. We examine works by artists like Hokusai and Hiroshige not just for their aesthetic and historical value, but for the stories they tell of everyday life. That is how the people of Edo themselves enjoyed this mass-produced medium.

programme.desc: Inami Shishimai is a type of lion dance performed in Toyama Prefecture. Adults play the role of the shishi while a child is the shishi-tori, whose job is to pacify the shishi with sacred objects.
programme.title: Matsuri: The Heartbeat of Japan - Season 1, Episode 1
programme.desc: Inami Shishimai is a type of lion dance performed in Toyama Prefecture. Here, the shishi symbolizes the harshness and bounty of the natural world, and the matsuri focuses on the importance of harmony between people and nature. Adults play the role of the enormous shishi while a child is the shishi-tori, whose job is to pacify the shishi with sacred objects. This event is also an opportunity for local families to wish for happy marriages and children, and the shishi dances in celebration.

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.desc: Documentary programme that allows viewers to discover more about the stunning Japan, through its incredible and long history, ancient traditions, local festivals, amazing and beloved food and daily life. Find out more about Japan's favorite citrus fruit, Ishigaki Island, "nabe" or hot pot, local train lines, Shinbashi, one of Tokyo's leading business districts, ''soba'' or Japan's beloved noodle, and much more.
programme.title: Magical Japanese - Season 1, Episode 1
Seasoning the Seasons
programme.desc: The Japanese language is rich in words and expressions influenced by nature, history and culture. This episode focuses on words related to doro, or mud. Since ancient times, Japanese people have gotten muddy in the rice paddies, cultivating their main staple. Perhaps because of this, there are a surprising number of expressions related to mud in Japanese. And reflecting such a place of hard work, many of them are used in business situations. From his home in Kyoto Prefecture, poet and literary translator Peter MacMillan guides us through unique words born from "mud."

Traveling across Japan, we can find many bridges of all shapes and sizes. In Tokyo, building modern bridges was one way to join the club of advanced industrial nations in the late 19th century, when Japan was vying to catch up with Western technology. A small bridge in Iwate Prefecture is hand-made. Even if relatively few people use it, it is an important crossing for the local community. Today, we hear the story of bridges linking communities throughout Japan.

programme.title: Matsuri: The Heartbeat of Japan - Season 1, Episode 1
Herbal Symphony #3 Autumn
programme.desc: Inami Shishimai is a type of lion dance performed in Toyama Prefecture. Here, the shishi symbolizes the harshness and bounty of the natural world, and the matsuri focuses on the importance of harmony between people and nature. Adults play the role of the enormous shishi while a child is the shishi-tori, whose job is to pacify the shishi with sacred objects. This event is also an opportunity for local families to wish for happy marriages and children, and the shishi dances in celebration.

programme.title: ヒトとサル：ハイブリッド生物の科学(二)
programme.desc: 2021年、ヒト幹細胞をサルの胚に入れて培養し、ヒトとサルの異種複合体が作られた。はたしてこれは禁断の科学なのか？それとも人間が病気を克服するための科学なのか？
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 【恐竜・古代生物】世界ミステリーハンター：氷河期タイムトラベル(二)

programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: ワイルドライフ24(二)
programme.desc: たった24時間でも世界中で様々なことが起きている。空の下では鳥がさえずり、は虫類が日光浴をし、ジャガーが狩りをし、ハゲワシが空高く舞い上がろうとしている。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.desc: 野生の王国アワー 猛スピードで攻撃するクサリヘビや、狩りの達人コヨーテ、狡猾なアジアチーターやオオトカゲなど、砂漠に暮らす暗殺者を紹介。

programme.title: 【アンコール一挙】BBC超大作 セレンゲティ物語 S2：災害による変化(二)
programme.desc: アンコール一挙 嵐の余波で、広範囲にわたり洪水が起きる。どの動物も高台を目指して必死に逃げようとするが、洪水は容赦なく襲いかかる。

programme.desc: 「世界動物の日」記念SP セレンゲティでは乾季に入り始め、群れ同士の競争が激しくなる。今回は、家族が生き残るために戦う群れの強いメスたちに迫る。

programme.title: セレブの告白 驚き動物体験記：ダダダン ブルドッグ(二)
programme.desc: オーストラリアでドラマ“サブリナ”の撮影をしていたメリッサ・ジョーン・ハートは、ハンドウイルカとの共演を楽しみにしていた。しかしハンドウイルカは非協力的で…。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 【ネイチャー特選】地球いきもの四季物語：春の訪れ(二)
programme.desc: ネイチャー特選 春は新しい生命が次々と誕生する魔法の季節であり、動物たちが目を覚まし、ほかのものに負けまいとする競争の季節でもある。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 【ネイチャー特選】地球いきもの四季物語：夏の活気(二)
programme.desc: ネイチャー特選 太陽が輝き、花が咲き誇る夏は日照時間が長く、動植物は活気に満ちている。そして夏がもたらす困難にどう立ち向かっているのか？
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 【ネイチャー特選】地球いきもの四季物語：秋の試練(二)
programme.desc: ネイチャー特選 足早に近づく冬に備え、蓄えを隠すものや子孫を残すために戦うものなど、秋がもたらす新たな困難に立ち向かう動植物を紹介する。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 【ネイチャー特選】地球いきもの四季物語：冬の世界(二)
programme.desc: ネイチャー特選 世界が雪や氷に覆われる冬、動物たちは生き残り、寒さという自然から恩恵を受けるため、独創的な方法を見つけなければならない。

programme.desc: アンコール一挙 動物界では新たな命が誕生するシーズンとなる。しかし、やがて嵐が吹き荒れ、平和な世界は悪夢へと変わる。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 【アンコール一挙】BBC超大作 セレンゲティ物語 S2：災害による変化(二)
programme.desc: アンコール一挙 嵐の余波で、広範囲にわたり洪水が起きる。どの動物も高台を目指して必死に逃げようとするが、洪水は容赦なく襲いかかる。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 【恐竜・古代生物】世界ミステリーハンター：氷河期タイムトラベル(二)
programme.desc: 恐竜・古代生物 ジョシュ・ゲイツが氷河期の謎に迫る。ロシアでマンモスのDNAサンプルを入手。サンプルをラボに持ち帰り分かったこととは。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 危険生物カウントダウン：北アメリカ(二)
programme.desc: アメリカは野生動物の宝庫だ。オオカミ、ハイイログマ、アリゲーターは人間を切り刻むことができる。しかし圧倒的な死者数を出しているのは、アフリカナイズドミツバチだ。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: インフォマーシャル(日)
programme.desc: 通販番組をお届けする30分
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: どうぶつ楽園ライフ：保護ハウスへようこそ(字)
programme.desc: リー・アッシャーは、会社生活をなげうって作った「アッシャーハウス」でアルパカの家族を作り、保護された怯えるマスティフに泳ぎを教える。そんな彼の奮闘を紹介する。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: どうぶつ楽園ライフ：ダイエット作戦(字)
programme.desc: 「アッシャーハウス」に角がひとつ折れたヒツジのアリエスが来る。マスティフのローザは恐怖心を克服して泳ごうと奮闘、犬のチャーリーは仲間に遅れないため減量が必要だ。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: インフォマーシャル(日)
programme.desc: 通販番組をお届けする30分
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 【ネイチャー特選】BBC超大作 ビッグキャット24時：危険な選択(二)
programme.desc: ネイチャー特選 リーダーが負傷し、危険にさらされるライオンの群れや、パートナーを探すメスのヒョウに密着。また、チーターの“ポベ”を捜す。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 【アンコール一挙】イギリス野生動物レスキュー：ムクドリ/ヒメアシナシトカゲ(二)
programme.desc: アンコール一挙 ハリネズミが保護される。体は青色で、何者かに塗られたようだ。急いで有害な物質を落とさなければ命が危ない。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 【アンコール一挙】イギリス野生動物レスキュー：マガモ/アザラシ/アナグマ(二)
programme.desc: アンコール一挙 7羽のマガモの赤ちゃんが卵からかえった。水も食べ物もなく、危険な状態だ。命を救うため厳しい決断を迫られる。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: インフォマーシャル(日)
programme.desc: 通販番組をお届けする30分
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: ヒトとサル：ハイブリッド生物の科学(二)
programme.desc: 2021年、ヒト幹細胞をサルの胚に入れて培養し、ヒトとサルの異種複合体が作られた。はたしてこれは禁断の科学なのか？それとも人間が病気を克服するための科学なのか？
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 【ネイチャー特選】BBC超大作 ザ・ハント：北極の掟(二)
programme.desc: ネイチャー特選 オオカミやホッキョクギツネ、ホッキョクグマなど北極の肉食動物たちは、変化する環境に絶えず適応するしか生き残る道はない。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: インフォマーシャル(日)
programme.desc: 通販番組をお届けする30分
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 【アンコール一挙】BBC超大作 セレンゲティ物語 S2：新たな世界(二)
programme.desc: アンコール一挙 洪水の被害が収まるにつれ、動物たちの関心は食料へと向かう。若い動物が狩りの方法を学ぶ一方、家族を失い悲しむ動物もいて…。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 【アンコール一挙】BBC超大作 セレンゲティ物語 S2：危険な時期(二)
programme.desc: アンコール一挙 新たな生命が続々と誕生するが、赤ん坊にとって今の時期は特に危険だ。ジャッカルやヒョウの子供たちは、ハイエナに襲われる。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 【「世界動物の日」記念SP】BBC超大作 セレンゲティ物語：侵略(二)
programme.desc: 「世界動物の日」記念SP すべての群れは年に一度の「大移動」を今か今かと待っている。大地はますます暑くなり、肉食動物たちに深刻な飢えが襲い始める。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: インフォマーシャル(日)
programme.desc: 通販番組をお届けする30分
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: どうぶつ楽園ライフ：新しい仲間(字)
programme.desc: 今回リーは、カリフォルニアからやってくるグレート・デーンのサージを待っている。一方、ぽっちゃり犬チャーリーの減量作戦で、新しいトレーニング法を試すことにする。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 【吹替版】デンバー動物クリニック S3：カルテ4(二)
programme.desc: 吹替版 脳を損傷し、命の危険がある犬やアゴを骨折した犬が運び込まれる。スタッフは、言うことを聞かない猫やヤクに手を焼く。

programme.title: 【吹替版】デンバー動物クリニック S3：カルテ5(二)
programme.desc: 吹替版 ジェフ先生とペトラ先生は、ハスキーの脚を治すため必死に治療する。また、膀胱結石で命の危険がある猫の緊急手術が行われる。

programme.title: 【すご腕アニマル！】ワイルドキャット〜野生の秘密〜：アフリカ(二)
programme.desc: すご腕アニマル！ チーターやヒョウ、ライオンのほかアフリカゴールデンキャット、カラカル、サーバルなどアフリカを象徴するネコ科動物を紹介。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: [新]BBC超大作 セレンゲティ物語 S3：安息の地を求めて(二)
programme.desc: ヒヒのバカリはリーダーの座を狙われ、メスライオンのカリは子育て中、マングースのウタ二は子守りの初日にチーターに遭遇する。一方、サバンナに大きな火事が差し迫る。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 冒険！世界ミステリーハンター S7：犯罪王 デリンジャー(二)
programme.desc: ジョシュ・ゲイツが今回探すのは、悪名高い銀行強盗、ジョン・デリンジャーの宝だ。デリンジャーの幼少時代の家を訪れ、ウィスコンシン州の極寒の湖にダイブする。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: 【11月は、犬の月！】かわいい！子犬と子猫：ブルドッグ訓練コース(字)
programme.desc: 11月は、犬の月！ アジリティーのコースでいいところを見せたいブルドッグの奮闘や、町で拾われた子犬たちと農場の家畜たちの出会いを紹介する。

programme.title: 【11月は、犬の月！】かわいい！子犬と子猫：ケアーンテリアと猫の友情(字)
programme.desc: 11月は、犬の月！ 気難しい同居ネコと仲良くなろうと奮闘するケアーンテリアや、正反対の性格の両親とサモエドの子どもたちの生活を追う。

programme.title: ねこ自慢：#54 出演：キンタロー。ほか(日)
programme.desc: 今回は、猫写真家が訪れた宮城県にある「猫の島」。その撮影旅行で４０匹の猫を激写！また、旦那様にヤキモチを焼く奥様が大好きなネコなどをご紹介。

programme.title: 【アンコール一挙】BBC超大作 セレンゲティ物語 S2：新たな世界(二)
programme.desc: アンコール一挙 洪水の被害が収まるにつれ、動物たちの関心は食料へと向かう。若い動物が狩りの方法を学ぶ一方、家族を失い悲しむ動物もいて…。
programme.category: ドキュメンタリー／教養

programme.title: Science View
programme.desc: Science for our future. Cutting edge research, innovation and technology being created by Japanese scientists and engineers.
There is a doctor who is working to develop drugs to treat myotonic dystrophy, an incurable disease. We take a closer look at Professor Masayuki NAKAMORI of Yamaguchi University and his challenge.
programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.desc: Sheila Cliffe follows Japan's silk road from Tomioka to the port of Yokohama where she encounters architecture designed for silkworms, modernized reeling machinery, weavers and historians.
Highlighting the cutting edge research, innovation, and technology being created by Japanese scientists and engineers.
programme.title: Science View - Season 1, Episode 1

Journeys in Japan is a documentary series where English-speaking guides explore Japan's diverse regions, delving into local traditions, culture, and everyday life, offering viewers a unique look beyond typical tourist spots.
programme.title: Journeys In Japan
programme.desc: In 1859, when Japan reopened its doors after more than two centuries of isolation, goods flowed in and out of newly expanded ports. At the time, raw silk became the country's largest export, as the silk industries in France and Italy had been hit by an epidemic of silkworm disease. At one point, Japan was the world's biggest exporter. On this episode of Journeys in Japan, Sheila Cliffe from the UK follows the Silk Road from northern Kanto, once a major production area, to Yokohama, where the silk took off to the world.

Ukiyo-e Edo-Life
programme.desc: With its splendid branches and white plum blossoms, this famous painting is known for captivating Van Gogh - discover why people were able to tell this was a specific tree at Kameido Umeyashiki.
In the pleasure quarters of Edo, a precious house cat stares longingly out the window at a crowd of people going to and fro. Telltale signs scattered about the room reveal why it appears to be upset.
With its splendid branches and white plum blossoms, this famous painting is known for captivating Van Gogh. Discover...

Centuries ago, Tokyo was known as Edo. More than a million people enjoyed life in this small but abundant city. They live on in ukiyo-e woodblock prints. Each episode is a deep dive into a single print, and an exploration of the soul of Old Tokyo. We examine works by artists like Hokusai and Hiroshige not just for their aesthetic and historical value, but for the stories they tell of everyday life. That is how the people of Edo themselves enjoyed this mass-produced medium.
programme.title: Ukiyoe Edo-Life
programme.sub-title: Plum Estate, Kameido by Utagawa Hiroshige

programme.title: Shiba Inu's Rule
programme.desc: An egoistic magazine editor in his forties finds himself completely alone at work-abandoned by colleagues, with only his Shiba Inu by his side. Inspired by the dog, he proposes a Shiba-themed magazine. Misfits are forced to collaborate, sparking friction and chaos. But through the dog's gentle gaze, ideas emerge, and broken hearts begin to heal.

programme.title: Night Serial Drama "Hirayasumi"
Hirayasumi, Ep 2
programme.desc: Ikuta Hiroto, 29. He has no full-time job, no partner, no plan for the future and he couldn't be happier. He's just fine, unfettered and carefree. One day, Hiroto ends up inheriting a "hiraya" (one-story house) from an elderly neighbor whom he befriended purely by his personable nature.
programme.title: Hirayasumi, Ep 2
programme.desc: Ikuta Hiroto, 29. Ia tidak memiliki pekerjaan penuh-waktu, tidak sama, tidak ada rencana untuk masa depan—dan dia tidak bisa lebih bahagia. Dia baik-baik saja, tak terkekang, dan riang. Suatu hari, Hiroto akhirnya mewarisi "hiraya" (rumah satu lantai) dari seorang tetangga tua yang dia jadikan teman murni karena kepribadiannya.
programme.title: Hirayasumi
programme.desc: A warm and bittersweet drama based on the internationally beloved manga by Shinzo Keigo. Ikuta Hiroto (Okayama Amane), 29, has no job, no romantic partner, and none of the usual worries about the future. Drawn to his easygoing personality, a local elderly woman gives him a single-story house. He begins living with his 18-year-old cousin Natsumi (Mori Nana), who has just moved to Tokyo from Yamagata. Before long, people carrying quiet burdens begin to gather around him.

New Japonism: Bon Dance

programme.title: Night Serial Drama "Hirayasumi"
Hirayasumi, Ep 1
programme.desc: Ikuta Hiroto, 29. He has no full-time job, no partner, no plan for the future and he couldn't be happier. He's just fine, unfettered and carefree. One day, Hiroto ends up inheriting a "hiraya" (one-story house) from an elderly neighbor whom he befriended purely by his personable nature.
programme.title: Hirayasumi, Ep 1
programme.desc: Ikuta Hiroto, 29. Ia tidak memiliki pekerjaan penuh-waktu, tidak sama, tidak ada rencana untuk masa depan—dan dia tidak bisa lebih bahagia. Dia baik-baik saja, tak terkekang, dan riang. Suatu hari, Hiroto akhirnya mewarisi "hiraya" (rumah satu lantai) dari seorang tetangga tua yang dia jadikan teman murni karena kepribadiannya.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Versatile Oil: Smoothing the Way in Everyday Life
programme.desc: Kyoto dominated the oil market 1,000 years ago. Various oils fueled votive lamps, flavored food, preserved wood, and were used in pomade and cosmetics. Oil still plays a key role in the culture today.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Outside in Lost in Academia
programme.desc: Norwegian sociolinguist Goran Vaage investigates Japanese laughter, or warai. He analyzes how comedy is ingrained into communication in everyday life and plays a vital role in social connection.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.desc: Dig deeper into current affairs. Cutting-edge information and critical analysis on important issues confronting Japanese lives.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Training Dogs to Save Lives Around the World
programme.desc: Murase Hidehiro trains search-and-rescue dogs to save lives in disaster areas around the world. He talks about the importance of having dogs that are specifically able to respond to disasters in Asia.

programme.title: DOSUKOI Sumo Salon
programme.desc: This is a move that can be used either for defense or offense. We take a deep dive into how it works and how it's been employed throughout sumo history to trip up even fearsome opponents!

programme.title: The Beauty of Japanese Swords: Famous Masterpieces
programme.desc: This time, a famous swordsmith's blade that was cherished by the shoguns who ruled Edo-period Japan.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: The Man with the Piercing Gaze
programme.desc: A man strikes a pose in an iconic woodblock print by the artist Sharaku. Who is the mysterious figure ... and what is he doing? And why did the artist want to commemorate the moment? *"The Actor Otani Oniji III as Edobei" (1794) by Toshusai Sharaku

programme.title: Hometown Stories
programme.sub-title: Chasing a Dream With a Horse
programme.desc: Nishino Masatoshi didn't know what he wanted to do with his life until he learned about horse logging. Now, he's chasing his dream in the forests of Hokkaido with the help of his trusty sidekick, Kap.

programme.title: Satoyama Kitchen Diary
programme.sub-title: Hot Days and Cool Nights Make Tasty Veggies
programme.desc: Hello, it's me, Tama! What do I do on hot summer days? I hide in the shade! This morning, Grandpa Makoto and Grandma Nobuko are shopping for summer veggies for today's feast. I hope they buy some for me, too!

programme.title: Japanology Plus
programme.desc: *First broadcast on November 6, 2025 Interest in sleep has been growing in Japan. From futuristic high-tech beds to advanced sleepwear, many new products are designed to improve sleep quality. We look at Japan's latest sleep trends.
